newsitem.title: USA: Apple second-quarter loss less than expected.
newsitem.headline: Apple second-quarter loss less than expected.

text.p: Apple Computer Inc. reported a loss for the latest quarter that was far lower than Wall Street expected, but said it will not return to profitability later this year, as it had predicted.

For its fiscal third quarter ended on June 27, Apple had a loss of $56 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with a loss of $32 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier. Last year's results included a $39 million gain on an investment.
The report by the computer maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., came nearly a week after it ousted Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Gilbert Amelio.
Analysts had forecast a loss of 61 cents a share, according to First Call, which tracks earnings estimates.
Revenue fell 23 percent to $1.7 billion from $2.2 billion.
Apple said it had strong sales in educational markets and abroad, contributing to a 6 percent increase in revenue from the fiscal second quarter, ended in March.
But the company said it will not report a profit in its fourth quarter. Apple executives said earlier this year that the company could report a profit as early as the September quarter.

"The company continues to progress with its restructuring initiatives, as is evidenced by the significant sequential decrease in operating expenses," Chief Financial Officer Fred Anderson said in a statement.
